repnme.cdata!: Uganda - Power Sector Development Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Power Sector Development
            Operation Project for Uganda were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            high, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: electricity shortages need to
            be addressed from both supply side (generation) and demand
            side (energy efficiency) as they complement each other; as
            evidenced by the results of the project that resulted in
            contributions of about 1,000 GWh from the 50 MW Mutundwe
            plant on the supply side over the 4 years, and about 10 GWh
            from the demand side, out of savings arising from energy
            efficiency measures. In view of the planned new major
            investments, the Government has to implement measures to
            improve institutional and financial performance in advance
            of these investments. These measures include plans to
            facilitate a financially sustainable sector in the medium
            term highlighting the sector committed investments including
            the associated financing and implementation plans. The post
            project closing events, arising out of not having adequate
            budget provisions to ensure the continuing operations of
            thermal plants highlight the need for the stakeholders to
            continue high level dialog on key policy issues beyond the
            project period.

repnme.cdata!: Uganda - Power Sector Development Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objectives of the Power
            Sector Development Operation Project in Uganda are to reduce
            short-term power shortages and financial imbalances, and
            facilitate orderly longer-term expansion of electricity
            service. In order to achieve these objectives, the Operation
            comprises: (a) a set of investments and policy measures
            designed to reduce the supply-demand gap until the Bujagali
            hydropower plant comes into service in 2011; (b) financial
            support for the Government to absorb a part of the high
            costs of short-term thermal power generation; and (c) policy
            measures aimed at making the sector financially viable,
            accelerating rural electrification, and moving towards a
            sector-wide approach for development. The project portion of
            the operation comprises two components. Component 1 will
            provide partial co-financing towards the capacity and energy
            charges of a 50MW thermal plant to be installed at Mutundwe,
            Kampala. Component 2 will provide Technical Assistance and
            Energy Efficiency. Activities under this component will
            include: (a) Energy Efficiency and Demand Side Management
            ;(b) Independent Evaluation of the Rural Electrification
            Program; (c) Poverty and Social Impact Analysis (PSIA); (d)
            Power Sector Medium-term Investment Plan; (e) Lake Victoria
            Transmission Ring Pre-feasibility and Feasibility Studies;
            (f) Kalagala Offset Tourism Development Plan; and (g) Energy
            Sector Communications Strategy.
